DOC.HEAD: Pentagon: No Major Withdrawal from Pacific Bases Planned
DOC.TEXT: U.S. military officials say they are not actively considering a major military withdrawal from East Asia, although Pentagon planners recently drafted a memorandum outlining such a possibility. The Asahi Shimbun and Washington Post reported this week that Pentagon officials were considering closing U.S. bases in the Philippines and withdrawing forces from South Korea and Japan. That policy was outlined in a paper discussed at a meeting Monday involving Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, but many other options also were discussed, Pentagon officials said Wednesday. One source said that no such withdrawal was being considered for the next two or three years. U.S. Pacific forces include 222,238 personnel _ 50,000 in Japan, 45,000 in Hawaii, 32,000 in South Korea, and 34,000 at sea, according to Pentagon statistics. Additionally, the United States operates two important bases in the Philippines.
DOC.HEAD: Concern Over Polluted Parks Hoped to Help Clean Air Act
DOC.TEXT: Air pollution is taking its toll on national parks and wilderness areas, says a lawmaker who expects that concern over removing the dangerous haze will produce bipartisan support for strengthening the Clean Air Act. ``I believe that when the public learns the extent of the damage to our natural and cultural heritage, there will be strong bipartisan support for our efforts,'' Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., said Wednesday at a news conference. Wyden is a member of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which early next year will take up clean air legislation. The full Senate is also expected to take up such legislation soon after it reconvenes in late January. Wyden said he wants to amend the act to strengthen the protections for the national parks and other public treasures. Although the 1977 Clean Air Act contains such an amendment, the Environmental Protection Agency has not enforced it fully, he said.
DOC.HEAD: Cajun Food Recalled by Producer
DOC.TEXT: About 1,000 pounds of a frozen pork and rice product is being recalled by a Louisiana processor because it might be contaminated with a food-poisoning organism, Listeria monocytogenes, according to the Agriculture Department. Bodin Foods Inc. of New Iberia, La., sells the product through small distributors in Arizona, California, Florida, Louisiana and Texas. It is sold frozen in vacuum-sealed plastic packages with the name ``Boo Dan (Boudin Link) Traditional Cajun Pudding'' on the label, and ``Est. 8214'' printed inside the USDA inspection seal on the label. A USDA spokesman said Wednesday the product is cooked pork and rice wrapped in a sausage casing, or link. Listeriosis was described as ``a rare but potentially serious'' disease. Most vulnerable are those with weakened immune systems, including infants, the elderly and the chronically ill. Symptoms in adults include the sudden onset of flu-like symptoms such as fever, chills, headache, backache, and sometimes abdominal pain and diarrhea. In newborns, symptoms include respiratory distress, refusal to drink and vomiting.
